content.text:
# List of Ukrainian flag officers losses during the Russo-Ukrainian war__disambig_1

During the course of the Russo-Ukrainian War, including the Russian takeover of Crimea, the War in Donbas and the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Ukrainian flag officers have become casualties including killed, captured or wounded.
List
{| class="wikitable sortable sticky-header" style="text-align:left;"
! Name
! Rank
! Position
! Date reported
! Status
! class="unsortable" | Notes
|-
| Serhiy Hayduk
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="1" |  Vice Admiral
| Admiral of the Ukrainian Navy
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="2014-03-19" | 19 March 2014
|
| Captured by pro-Russian forces along 8 other officials. Released after order of the Russian MOD.
|-
| Mykhailo Koval
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="1" |  Colonel General
| Ministry of Defense and Commander of Border Troops
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="2022-03-01" | 5 March 2014
|
| Captured by Russian Airborne Forces and Russian civilians in Crimea. Released one day after.
|-
| Serhii Kulchytskyi
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="1" |  Major General}}
| Head of the Combat and Special Training Department of the Main Directorate of the National Guard
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="2014-05-29" | 29 May 2014
|
| Killed alongside 12 other servicemen when their Mil Mi-8 helicopter was shot down in Sloviansk.
|-
| Mykhailo Kutsyn
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="1" |  Lieutenant General
|  Chief of the General Staff and Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of Ukraine
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="2022-03-01" | 2 July 2014
|
| Shell-shocked on 2 July 2014 while combating the 2014 insurgency in Donbass. Dismissed by President Petro Poroshenko.[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-28144334 Ukraine's new defence minister promises Crimea victory], BBC News (3 July 2014)[http://www.ukrinform.ua/eng/news/president_appoints_muzhenko_as_commander_in_chief_of_armed_forces_323346 President appoints Muzhenko as commander-in-chief of Armed Forces], Ukrinform (3 July 2014)
|-
| Ihor Fedorovych Momot
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="1" |  Major General (posthumously)
| Deputy Head of the Eastern Regional Office of Security Service of Ukraine
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="2022-03-01" | 11 July 2014
|
| Killed by a Grad salvo during the Zelenopillia rocket attack.
|-
| Oleksandr Vitalijovych Radiyevs'kyj
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="1" |  Major General (posthumously)
| Commander of the 21st Separate Public Order Protection Brigade
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="2014-7-23" | 23 July 2014
|
|Ambushed alongside Col. P. Snitsar and a soldier in Lysychansk.
|-
| Isa Munayev
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="1" |  Brigadier General of Chechen Army
| Commander of the Dzhokhar Dudayev Battalion
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="2014-7-23" | 1 February 2015
|
| Killed during the Battle of Debaltseve
|-
| Maksym Shapoval
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="1" |  Major General (posthumously)
| Commander of the  of GUR
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="2022-03-01" | 27 June 2017
|
| Killed by a car bombing in Kyiv, Russian attack. See
|-
|
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="1" |  Brigadier General
| Chief of Staff and Deputy Commander of Ukrainian Air Assault Forces.
| class=nowrap data-sort-value="2022-03-01" | 4 November 2022
|
| Reportedly killed along Col. Volodymyr Oleksiyovych Levchuk after a mine hit their vehicle in Zhytomyr, according to Russian sources on 9 November 2022. Death was confirmed on 4 November 2024, by the Zhytomyr City Council.
|}
